text:
The Everett House 17th St. and 4th Ave., n.w. corner.

1874

Photograph by Brown Brothers
220 West 42nd St.
New York City

45 East 17th Street at the N.W. corner of Fourth Ave., facing on Union Square. This is the old Everett House and is now the site of the Everett Building. Also seen is Fourth Ave., west side, north from 17th, to but not including 18th Streets.
About 1890.

Stamp of The New York Public Library Astor, Lenox, and Tilden Foundations.

West side of Fourth Avenue north, from 17th Street. White building in centre is the once famous Everett House, a hotel named for Edward Everett, New england orator. The hotel stood at the N.E. corner of Fourth Avenue and 17th Street, overlooking Union Square on the South.

Brown Brothers, Photographers.
1906.

East side of Fourth Avenue, north from 17th Street.
Building on S.E. corner at extreme right is on present site of Tammany Hall.

Brown Brothers, Photographers.

1906.

Fourth Ave., east side, from East 17th to 18th Streets. The Guardian Life Insurance Building, at the N.E. corner of East 17th Street, is known as No. 50 Union Square, East.
About 1910.

W. D. Hassler.

The Everett House. East 17th Street, at the Northwest corner of 4th Avenue, looking north on the latter.
January 2, 1910.

17th Street, 4th Avenue to Broadway. (Before Reconstruction).
March 17, 1918.

17th Street (east), west from an including Fourth Ave., to and including Broadway. The view also shows Broadway, north from but not including 16th Street, and Fourth Ave., east side, north from but not including 16th, to and including 20th Streets. The northern extremity of Union Square, is also seen in the foreground.
About 1920.
Ewing Galloway.

(1)
17th Street (east), west from but not including Fourth Ave., to and including Broadway. Also shown is Broadway, north from and including 17th Street, to and including 18th Street. Union Square West, at, adjoining and south of the S.W. corner of 17th Street, is also seen. In the foreground appears the northern extremity of Union Square Park.

October 30, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing the northern part of Union Square West, in the foreground, and 17th Street, in the background.

March 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Similar to No. 3. Note the demolition of the Jackson building, No. 31 E. 17th Street.

June 7, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

Transportation--Trucks: A truckload of wastepaper at East 17th Street and Fourth Avenue and a Sanitation Department truck at West and West 10th streets, both in Manhattan.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: February 20, 1930
View 2: October 1, 1938
title: Transportation - Trucks.
